head.title: Water-in-Salt Electrolyte Enables Ultrafast Supercapacitors for AC Line Filtering | ACS Energy Letters

meta.content: Water-in-Salt Electrolyte Enables Ultrafast Supercapacitors for AC Line Filtering

Water-in-salt electrolytes (WiSEs) are a promising candidate for use in energy storage devices because of their wide electrochemical stability window (ESW) that overcomes the thermodynamic limit of water electrolysis (1.23 V). Despite the high energy density arising from the wide ESW, it is assumed that the power density of WiSE-based energy storage devices will always be less than those that operate with dilute electrolytes because of the higher viscosity of WiSEs. However, the present study demonstrates that ion transport in a high-concentration WiSE (17 m NaClO4) can be as fast as that in a dilute electrolyte (1 m NaClO4), facilitating the ultrafast operation of a supercapacitor. Because of this rapid ion transport, the WiSE-based supercapacitor is proven to be sufficiently fast for use in a 60 Hz AC line filtering application. This unexpectedly high response speed can be attributed to the unique biphasic structure of water and ion-aggregate networks in the WiSE.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
Recently, highly concentrated aqueous electrolytes, referred to as water-in-salt electrolytes (WiSEs), have attracted significant attention in the development of energy storage devices.
(1−4)
Despite the excellent characteristics of conventional aqueous electrolytes, such as low volatility, nonflammability, high conductivity, environmental friendliness, and low cost, their applications have been greatly limited because of their narrow electrochemical stability window (ESW).
(5,6)
On the other hand, WiSEs have a broad ESW that extends past the thermodynamic limit of water electrolysis (1.23 V), meaning that they are promising electrolytes for use in energy storage devices such as Li- and Na-ion batteries and supercapacitors.
(7−9)
The broad ESW of WiSEs is associated with a reduction in the number of free water molecules and intimate water–ion interactions in solutions with high salt concentrations.
(1,4,7)
While there has been significant focus on enhancing the energy density of energy storage devices based on a broad ESW, research into the power performance of WiSE-based energy devices has been very limited.
(2,4,10,11)
This is because, in general, there is a trade-off between energy density and power density, and it is naturally expected that the high viscosity of WiSEs arising from their extremely high salt concentrations will have a negative impact on their power performance.
(12,13)

However, interestingly, very recent studies involving molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and spectroscopic characterization have indicated that, despite their extremely high viscosity, WiSEs can exhibit decent ionic conductivity because of their unique electrolytic structure.
(14,15)
For example, 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) had a viscosity that was approximately 24 times greater than that of 1 m LiTFSI (28.5 vs 1.2 mm
2
s
–1
), while the conductivity of 21 m LiTFSI was only 4 times less (8.2 vs 30 mS cm
–1
).
(1)
This unexpectedly high conductivity was explained by the electrolytic structure of the 21 m LiTFSI, which consisted of a network of ion aggregates that were intricately intertwined with a network of channel-like water structures. Li ions could thus readily travel through this percolating water network during the charging and discharging processes of a Li-ion battery.
(14,15)

Of the various WiSEs that have been investigated, 17 m sodium perchlorate (NaClO
4
) has demonstrated particularly outstanding electrolyte properties. It exhibits a much higher ionic conductivity (64.2 mS cm
–1
) and lower viscosity (5.0 mm
2
s
–1
) than 21 m LiTFSI.
(4)
In fact, the conductivity of 17 m NaClO
4
is even greater than that of its dilute counterpart.
(4,16,17)
In addition, MD simulations and infrared spectroscopy suggest that 17 m NaClO
4
has a water network structure similar to that of 21 m LiTFSI.
(15,18,19)
Upon employment of the 17 m NaClO
4
in Na-ion batteries and supercapacitors, the energy storage devices exhibited decent power performance. However, we speculate that the study on the fast ion transport of the WiSEs has been limited because of the slow operation speed of those devices.
(4,20−23)
The operating speed of 17 m NaClO
4
-based batteries is relatively slow because their storage mechanism is based on chemical ion intercalation. Conventional supercapacitors are faster than batteries because of their use of a storage mechanism based on physical ion adsorption and desorption.
(13)
Nevertheless, the complicated pore structure of activated carbon, which is the dominant commercial electrode material in supercapacitors, is a considerable obstacle to studying fast ion-transport behavior and to exploiting the full potential of WiSEs.
(24,25)

To reveal the intrinsic ion-transport behavior of WiSEs, energy storage devices much faster than batteries and conventional supercapacitors are required. Suitable candidates in this regard are ultrafast supercapacitors developed specifically for AC line filtering applications.
(26−28)
This type of supercapacitor is fabricated mostly with unconventional carbon materials such as graphene nanosheets, carbon nanotubes, ordered mesoporous carbon, and Ketjenblack (KB).
(26−34)
Unlike activated carbon, these materials have much more open and straightforward pore structures. Thus, supercapacitors that employ these carbon materials greatly exceed the response speed of conventional supercapacitors and can maintain capacitive properties even for AC signals at frequencies of 60 Hz or higher. In contrast, activated carbon supercapacitors lose their capacitive properties completely and simply act as a resistor at 60 Hz.
(35,36)
Moreover, fast-responding supercapacitors are compact and considered a promising candidate to replace the bulky aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs) that are currently used for AC line filtering, which will contribute to the miniaturization of electronic devices.
(26,27,36)
However, most studies to date on ultrafast supercapacitors capable of AC line filtering have focused solely on carbon electrode materials.
(37,38)
Therefore, the investigation and development of new electrolytes such as WiSEs will greatly advance the performance of AC line filtering supercapacitors.

In this work, we demonstrate for the first time that ion transport in a highly concentrated electrolyte can be as effective as that in a dilute electrolyte. Uniform thin films consisting of KB and single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) (weight ratio 9:1) are used as an electrode to avoid limitations due to complicated pore structures and to explore the full potential of WiSEs. A 17 m NaClO
4
-based supercapacitor exhibits power performance comparable to that of a 1 m NaClO
4
-based counterpart over a wide range of frequencies (10
–1
to 10
4
Hz). Because of this fast response, the WiSE-based supercapacitor is successfully employed in an AC line filtering circuit and effectively converts a 60 Hz AC signal into a stable DC signal. The WiSE-based supercapacitor also exhibits an energy density that is 2.4 times greater than that of the supercapacitor based on a dilute electrolyte because of the enhanced ESW of the WiSE (2.5 V).

KB powder has an open mesoporous structure and a high specific surface area, which makes it a particularly promising electrode material for high-frequency supercapacitors. The field-emission transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image in
Figure
1
a shows that spherical KB particles are interconnected to form clusters of chain-like structures. The small primary KB particles have a diameter of 20.3 ± 6.3 nm (average ± standard deviation, sample number = 50) and an inner pore size of 13.6 ± 4.1 nm, which are estimated from TEM images (
Figure S1a
). The secondary KB network structure has a large volume fraction of mesopores between neighboring KB particles and adjacent KB clusters.
(33,39)
The KB powder has a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area of ∼1090 m
2
g
–1
.
(33)

The high graphiticity of KB particles ensures the high electrical conductivity of KB-based electrode films. The magnified TEM image in
Figure
1
b reveals graphitic layers in the KB particles with an interplanar distance of ∼4.0 Å.
(40,41)
There are also two X-ray diffraction (XRD) peaks centered at 22.3° and 43.4°, which correspond to the (002) and (101) planes of hexagonal graphite, respectively (
Figure
1
c). Compared to pure graphite, the peak positions shift toward a lower angle. The interlayer spacing calculated based on the (002) peak position is approximately 4.0 Å, slightly larger than that of pure graphite (∼3.4 Å). Raman spectroscopy also shows the graphitic nature of the KB powder, with D- and G-bands along with their overtone and combination bands clearly observed in
Figure S1b
.
(42−45)
X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis also confirms the graphitic characteristics of the KB powder. The survey scan spectrum reveals the presence of carbon and oxygen elements with a high C/O atomic ratio (C:O = 94:6) (
Figure S1c
), which is consistent with the result of energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy in scanning electron microscope (SEM) (C:O = 91:9). The deconvolution of the C 1s peak further reveals a high content of sp
2
(C=C) graphitic carbon compared to sp
3
(C–C) amorphous carbon (sp
2
:sp
3
of ∼3.2:1) (
Figure
1
d).

Uniform KB-SWNT thin-film electrodes are fabricated with KB nanoparticles and SWNTs with a weight ratio of 9:1. The small amount of SWNTs creates an electrical network and provides mechanical stability in the KB-SWNT films. The SEM image in
Figure
1
e clearly shows well-distributed KB clusters interconnected by highly conductive SWNTs. The SWNTs have a one-dimensional structure with a high length-to-diameter ratio, allowing them to conform and adhere well to the KB nanoparticles. Without the SWNTs, KB films are easily fractured during the fabrication process.
(33)
The SWNTs also allow for the robust adhesion between a KB-SWNT film and a current collector. Moreover, KB-SWNT films have an open mesoporous structure, which provides a high ion-accessible surface area and promotes fast ion transport. In this study, the as-prepared KB-SWNT thin films exhibit a high uniformity in their thickness (
Figure
1
f), with an average thickness of 1.45 ± 0.17 μm (sample number = 300) for a mass loading of 40 μg per cm
2
. The ultrafast response of KB-SWNT supercapacitors has been previously demonstrated with conventional dilute electrolytes.
(33)
This means that KB-SWNT films have a sufficiently straightforward pore structure for the investigation of ion-transport behavior in high-concentration electrolytes.

The solvation structures of low- (1 m) and high-concentration (17 m) NaClO
4
aqueous electrolytes differ considerably, as indicated by MD simulations, infrared (IR) analysis, and Raman spectroscopy.
(19,46−48)
In the 1 m NaClO
4
aqueous electrolyte, the cations (Na
+
) and anions (ClO
4
–
) are surrounded by a large number of water molecules and are isolated from each other (
Figure
2
a).
(19)
In contrast, in the 17 m NaClO
4
aqueous electrolyte, highly concentrated cations and anions aggregate together and form a percolating network structure (
Figure
2
b). This ion network is a framework that provides open spaces through which water permeates and forms a corresponding water network. The ion and water networks are intricately intertwined with each other as described elsewhere.
(19,46,47)
The formation of the ion network in WiSEs is possibly due to the lack of water molecules and the chaotropic nature of ClO
4
–
anions, which disrupts the hydrogen bonds in the water structure, facilitating the electrostatic interaction between ClO
4
–
anions and Na
+
cations (
Figures S2 and S3
).
(19,46−48)

Figure 2. Solvation shell structures of (a) low- (1 m) and (b) high-concentration (17 m) NaClO
4
-based aqueous electrolytes (white, H; red, O; green, Cl; and purple, Na). (c–e) Determination of the electrochemical stability window (ESW) of the 1 m and 17 m NaClO
4
electrolytes. Hydrogen and oxygen evolution regions are colored blue and pink, respectively. (c) Linear sweep voltammetry curves of each electrolyte measured with a KB-SWNT working electrode (
v
= 10 mV s
–1
). Enlarged graphs in the (d) cathodic and (e) anodic regions. Blue and pink lines (in panels d and e) indicate a cutoff current density of 0.2 mA cm
–2
.

The ESWs of 1 m and 17 m NaClO
4
are determined to be approximately 1.7 and 2.5 V, respectively, based on the cutoff current density of 0.2 mA cm
–2
in linear sweep voltammetry (
Figure
2
c–e). According to the suggested criterion, the ESW of the 1 m NaClO
4
electrolyte ranges from −0.68 to 1.06 V (vs Ag/AgCl), which correspond to the hydrogen reduction and water oxidation potentials, respectively.
(49)
The ESW of 17 m NaClO
4
ranges between −1.31 and 1.21 V (vs Ag/AgCl), which is much wider than the thermodynamic limit of water electrolysis (1.23 V). Previously reported ESWs for 17 m NaClO
4
have exhibited great variation (2.4–3.2 V).
(4,17,20−23,50)
The ESWs for batteries are relatively wider than those for supercapacitors because of the presence of solid electrolyte interphases at the electrode/electrolyte interface.
(21)
The ESWs of supercapacitors are dependent on how polarizable the electrode material is.

The extended ESW of 17 m NaClO
4
can be attributed to its unique water structure when compared to dilute electrolytes.
(4,18,19,46−48)
In highly concentrated electrolytes, the number of water molecules surrounding each ion is sufficiently low that the hydrogen-bonding network between the water molecules is disrupted. In addition, there are not enough water molecules to neutralize the electrostatic field generated by the ions. This leads to the stronger hydration of the individual ions and the stronger interactions between the cations and anions, facilitating the formation of ion aggregates and an ion network. Interestingly, the widening of the ESW in 17 m NaClO
4
is observed mainly on the negative side of the window, where the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) occurs (from −0.68 to −1.31 V vs Ag/AgCl) (
Figure
2
c,d). This indicates that the HER is greatly suppressed in WiSEs, which is possibly related to the disrupted hydrogen-bonding network of water. In particular, weaker hydrogen bonds between water molecules lead to stronger O–H bonds within individual water molecules.
(22,51)
In other words, the suppression of the HER may be associated with the enhanced strength of the O–H bonds in water molecules in 17 m NaClO
4
. In contrast, the ESW on the positive side was mostly invariant regardless of the concentration of the electrolyte (from 1.06 to 1.21 V vs Ag/AgCl) (
Figure
2
c,e). This difference may be related to the different orientation of the water molecules at the surface of the negative and positive electrodes and around cations and anions.
(51)
However, further investigation is necessary to clearly explain the differences in behavior on either side of the ESW.

Because of the wider ESW, the KB-SWNT supercapacitor with 17 m NaClO
4
exhibits a cell operating voltage greater than that with 1 m NaClO
4
(2.3 vs 1.6 V) (
Figure
3
a–d). The cell voltage is determined by investigating how the potentials of the positive and negative electrodes vary as a function of the ESW during the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) process (
Figure
3
a,b). In general, when the supercapacitor is charging, the potentials of the positive and negative electrodes depart from the common rest potential and move away from each other linearly and symmetrically. Unless the rest potential is located exactly in the middle of the ESW, one of the potentials reaches one of the boundaries of the ESW first. This means that the operating cell voltage is narrower than the ESW. For example, in the 1 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor, the potentials of the positive and negative electrodes change from a rest potential of 0.16 to 0.93 V and −0.68 V (vs Ag/AgCl), respectively (
Figure
3
a). The negative electrode reaches the hydrogen evolution potential (−0.68 V vs Ag/AgCl) first, before the positive electrode has reached the water oxidation potential. This restricts the cell operating voltage,
i.e.
, the difference in potential between the two electrodes, to 1.6 V.

Figure 3. Electrochemical performance of KB-SWNT supercapacitors with a 1 m or 17 m NaClO
4
electrolyte in a two-electrode configuration (mass = 40 μg cm
–2
). Voltage profiles of the positive and negative electrodes (
I
= 10 mA cm
–2
) of the supercapacitors with (a) 1 m or (b) 17 m NaClO
4
electrolyte. (c) Cyclic voltammetry (CV) (
v
= 10 V s
–1
) and (d) galvanostatic charge–discharge curves (
I
= 10 mA cm
–2
). (e) Plot of areal capacitances (
C
areal
) vs current density. (f) Cyclic voltammograms at high scan rates with the 17 m NaClO
4
-based supercapacitor.

In the 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor, the potentials of the positive and negative electrodes move from a rest potential of 0.05 to 1.15 V and −1.15 V (vs Ag/AgCl), respectively (
Figure
3
b). As a result of the wider ESW, the 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor exhibits a higher cell operating voltage. Unlike the 1 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor, the positive electrode in the 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor reaches the potential for water oxidation first because the negative limit has been significantly extended because of the suppression of the HER. This leads to a higher cell voltage of 2.3 V. Both KB-SWNT supercapacitors with 1 m and 17 m NaClO
4
demonstrate typical behavior of an electrical double-layer capacitor, with rectangular cyclic voltammograms (
Figures
3
c and
S4
), triangular GCD curves (at 10 mA cm
–2
) (
Figure
3
d) during the charge/discharge cycle, and excellent cycle stability (retention ∼97% with 17 m and ∼100% with 1 m NaClO
4
after 10 000 cycles,
Figure S5
) within the determined cell voltages.

In addition to the increased cell voltage, the 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor exhibits a higher areal capacitance (
C
areal
, 1422.2 vs 1177.2 μF cm
–2
at 1 mA cm
–2
) and equivalent rate capability than does the 1 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor (
Figure
3
e). A higher areal capacitance is observed for the 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor over all measured current densities (1–10 mA cm
–2
). The enhanced capacitance of the WiSE supercapacitor can be attributed to the higher charge density in the electrical double layer (EDL), which is possibly due to the smaller size of the hydrated ions caused by a lack of water molecules and/or a higher cell voltage. The 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor also exhibits an excellent rate capability of ∼94% as the current density increases from 1 to 10 mA cm
–2
(from 1422.2 to 1330.6 μF cm
–2
), comparable to that of the 1 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor (∼96%, from 1177.2 to 1125.0 μF cm
–2
). Interestingly, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves for the 17 m NaClO
4
-based supercapacitor maintain a rectangular shape even for a high scan rate of 300 V s
–1
, indicating that rapid ion movement in WiSEs is indeed possible (
Figure
3
f).

Fast ion transport in WiSE is further verified using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis (
Table
1
). The frequency response of the 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor is comparable to that of the 1 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor, even with its 5 times higher viscosity.
(4)
The Bode-phase plots for the supercapacitors employing high- and low-concentration electrolytes show a similar phase angle (Φ) of −78.7 and −77.6° at 120 Hz, respectively (
Figure
4
a). A higher capacitance is observed for the 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor at 120 Hz (901 vs 789 μF cm
–2
) (
Figure
4
b). The 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor also exhibits an areal energy density (
E
areal
) that is 2.4 times greater than that of the 1 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor at 120 Hz because of the higher capacitance and cell voltage (0.662 vs 0.281 μWh cm
–2
). The WiSE supercapacitor represents a gravimetric energy density 1.5 times greater than that of the 1 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor (0.40 vs 0.26 μWh g
–1
at 120 Hz) owing to the increased cell voltage (1.6 → 2.3 V) despite the higher electrolyte mass. For the gravimetric energy density calculation, the mass of both electrodes (80 μg) and electrolytes (1 m, 1.07 g; and 17 m, 1.68 g; the volume of electrolyte = 1 mL) were considered. The Nyquist plots present a low equivalent series resistance (ESR) of 0.2–0.3 Ω and nearly vertical lines, indicating excellent capacitive behavior without diffusion limitations (
Figure
4
c). The above capacitance and resistance values of 17 m and 1 m NaClO
4
supercapacitors correspond well with the results determined by EIS fitting analysis (
Figure S6 and Table S1
). In addition, both supercapacitors exhibit small relaxation time constants (τ
0
< 2 ms) as indicated by the peak positions in
Figure S7a
. The excellent frequency response of the WiSE supercapacitor is consistent with the existence of fast ion transport through the channel-like water structure in WiSEs.
(14,15)
While previous reports have described only the rapid transport of cations (
e.g.
, Li
+
), the fast response of supercapacitors with symmetric positive and negative electrodes confirms the rapid transport of anions (
e.g.
, ClO
4
–
) as well. In addition, the WiSE supercapacitors exhibit highest
E
areal
among various aqueous-electrolyte-based supercapacitors, which is even comparable to those of organic-electrolyte-based supercapacitors (
Figure S8
).
(26,31−33,52−56)

Figure 4. Frequency response comparison of 1 m and 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitors (mass loading = 40 μg cm
–2
). (a) Phase angle and (b) areal capacitance (
C
areal
) with respect to frequency. (c) Nyquist plots. Frequency responses of 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitors with different mass loadings for the KB-SWNT electrode (mass loading = 30, 40, 50, 60, and 70 μg cm
–2
). (d) Bode-phase plots. (e)
C
areal
vs frequency plots. (f) Nyquist plots.

div.div:
Table 1. Properties of KB-SWNT Supercapacitors with 1 m or 17 m NaClO
4
Electrolyte (Mass Loading = 40 μg cm
–2
)

div.p:
WiSE supercapacitors also exhibit a trade-off between the capacitance and response speed with respect to the mass loading of KB-SWNT (
Table
2
). An increase in the loading mass of the electrode materials leads to a higher areal capacitance and a slower response speed due to the higher surface area and the longer travel distance for the electrolyte ions, respectively.
(32,33)
When the loading mass of the KB-SWNT electrodes increases from 30 to 70 μg cm
–2
,
C
areal
and the impedance phase angle gradually change from 621 to 1637 μF cm
–2
and from −80.7 to −69.1° at 120 Hz, respectively (
Figure
4
d,e). The Nyquist plots retain their vertical lines with little variation in the ESR (0.23–0.28 Ω), as shown in
Figure
4
f. The relaxation time constants (τ
0
) of the supercapacitors increase mildly from 0.9 to 3.2 ms while remaining sufficiently small for 60 Hz AC line filtering (
Figure S7b
). The capacitance and response speed of WiSE supercapacitors are comparable to those of 1 m NaClO
4
-based supercapacitors over the entire range of the mass loadings of KB-SWNT studied in this work (
Figure S9 and Table S2
).

div.div:
Table 2. Properties of 17 m NaClO
4
Supercapacitors with Different Mass Loadings

div.p:
An AC line filtering circuit equipped with a WiSE supercapacitor successfully converts a 60 Hz AC signal to a DC signal. The circuit consists of a full-wave bridge rectifier, a WiSE supercapacitor, and a load resistor.
(31−33)
A function generator supplies sinusoidal AC voltage (
V
peak
= ±2.49 V, 60 Hz) as the input signal to the circuit (
Figure
5
a). The AC signal is then converted to a 120 Hz pulsating DC signal (
V
= 0–2.28 V) by the full-bridge rectifier, which is composed of four diodes (
Figure
5
b). Lastly, the rectified pulsating signal is smoothed to a constant DC output (∼2.08 V) using the parallel resistor–capacitor circuit (
Figure
5
c). The smooth DC output waveform without ripple voltage corroborates the excellent AC line filtering performance of the WiSE-based supercapacitor.

Figure 5. Alternating current (AC) line filtering performance of the 17 m NaClO
4
-based supercapacitor (mass loading = 40 μg cm
–2
). (a) AC input (
V
peak
= ± 2.49 V, 60 Hz), (b) rectified pulsating DC (
V
= 0–2.28 V, 120 Hz), and (c) constant DC output (∼2.08 V, 10 kΩ).

We demonstrated ultrafast WiSE supercapacitors capable of 60 Hz AC line filtering. A KB-SWNT thin film was used as an electrode, offering a high specific surface area, an open porous structure, and high electrical conductivity, all of which are suitable for investigating fast ion-transport behavior of electrolytes during cell operation. Despite its 5 times higher viscosity, the 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor exhibited a rapid response speed that was comparable to that of the 1 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor characterized by a rectangular CV curve up to 300 V s
–1
, a high negative phase angle (−Φ = 78.7 vs 77.6° at 120 Hz), a high areal capacitance (901 vs 789 μF cm
–2
at 120 Hz), and a low ESR (0.24 vs 0.33 Ω). Because of this rapid response, an AC line filtering circuit equipped with a WiSE supercapacitor successfully converted AC input (
V
peak
= ± 2.49 V, 60 Hz) to constant DC output (∼2.08 V). The rapid ion transport in WiSEs during actual supercapacitor operation was attributed to the unique biphasic intertwined network structure of water molecules and ion aggregates, as suggested by other researchers. Furthermore, the 17 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor exhibited a higher operating cell voltage (2.3 vs 1.6 V), leading to an areal energy density that was approximately 2.4 times greater than that of the 1 m NaClO
4
supercapacitor (0.281 → 0.662 μWh cm
–2
at 120 Hz). Finally, the WiSE supercapacitor exhibited greater capacitance (621 to 1637 μF cm
–2
at 120 Hz) and a lower negative phase angle (−Φ = 80.7° to 69.1° at 120 Hz) as the mass loading increased (30 to 70 μg per electrode). We believe our work will stimulate further research on concentrated aqueous electrolytes and contribute to the development of high-performance energy storage devices.

"Water-in-salt" electrolyte enables high-voltage aqueous lithium-ion chemistries
Suo, Liumin; Borodin, Oleg; Gao, Tao; Olguin, Marco; Ho, Janet; Fan, Xiulin; Luo, Chao; Wang, Chunsheng; Xu, Kang

Lithium-ion batteries raise safety, environmental, and cost concerns, which mostly arise from their nonaq. electrolytes. The use of aq. alternatives is limited by their narrow electrochem. stability window (1.23 V), which sets an intrinsic limit on the practical voltage and energy output. We report a highly concd. aq. electrolyte whose window was expanded to ∼3.0 V with the formation of an electrode-electrolyte interphase. A full lithium-ion battery of 2.3 V using such an aq. electrolyte was demonstrated to cycle up to 1000 times, with nearly 100% coulombic efficiency at both low (0.15 C) and high (4.5 coulombs) discharge and charge rates.

Jiang, Liwei; Liu, Lilu; Yue, Jinming; Zhang, Qiangqiang; Zhou, Anxing; Borodin, Oleg; Suo, Liumin; Li, Hong; Chen, Liquan; Xu, Kang; Hu, Yong-Sheng

H2O-in-salt (WiS) electrolytes provide a new pathway to widen the electrochem. window of aq. electrolytes. However, their formulation strongly depends on the soly. of the chosen salts, imposing a stringent restriction on the no. of possible WiS systems. This issue becomes more severe for aq. Na-ion batteries (ANIBs) owing to the relatively lower soly. of Na salts compared to its alk. cousins (Li, K, and Cs). A new class of the inert-cation-assisted WiS (IC-WiS) electrolytes contg. the Et4N+ (TEA+) inert cation is reported. The Na IC-WiS electrolyte at a superhigh concn. of 31 mol kg-1 exhibits a wide electrochem. window of 3.3 V, suppresses transition metal dissoln. from the cathode, and ensures singular intercalation of Na into both cathode and anode electrodes during cycling, which is often problematic in mixed alkali cation systems such as K-Na and Li-Na. Owing to these unique advantages of the IC-WiS electrolyte, the NaTiOPO4 anode and Prussian blue analog Na1.88Mn[Fe(CN)6]0.97·1.35H2O cathode can be coupled to construct a full ANIB, delivering an av. voltage of 1.74 V and a high energy d. of 71 Wh kg-1 with a capacity retention of 90% after 200 cycles at 0.25 C and of 76% over 800 cycles at 1C.

Aq. electrolytes have shown extraordinary promise for safe electrochem. energy storage devices, but their widespread use is severely limited by the narrow electrochem. stability window (ESW). Here the great feasibility is demonstrated of using a superconcd. sodium perchlorate aq. soln. as a low-cost "water-in-salt" electrolyte to construct a high-performance carbon-based supercapacitor (SC). The attractive features of this electrolyte including wide ESW and excellent cond. enable the model SC to fully work at 2.3 V with superior rate capability and outstanding cycling stability. This SC exhibits a comparable energy d., a higher power d. and a much lower price compared to com. non-aq. SCs working at 2.7 V, representing significant progress toward practical applications.

Concentrated mixed cation acetate "water-in-salt" solutions as green and low-cost high voltage electrolytes for aqueous batteries
Lukatskaya, Maria R.; Feldblyum, Jeremy I.; Mackanic, David G.; Lissel, Franziska; Michels, Dominik L.; Cui, Yi; Bao, Zhenan

Electrolyte solns. are a key component of energy storage devices that significantly impact capacity, safety, and cost. Recent developments in "water-in-salt" (WIS) aq. electrolyte research have enabled the demonstration of aq. Li-ion batteries that operate with capacities and cyclabilities comparable with those of com. non-aq. Li-ion batteries. Critically, the use of aq. electrolyte mitigates safety risks assocd. with non-aq. electrolytes. However, the high cost and potential toxicity of imide-based WIS electrolytes limit their practical deployment. In this report, we disclose the efficacy of inexpensive, non-toxic mixed cation electrolyte systems for Li-ion batteries that otherwise provide the same benefits as current WIS electrolytes: extended electrochem. stability window and compatibility with traditional intercalation Li-ion battery electrode materials. We take advantage of the high soly. of potassium acetate to achieve the WIS condition in a eutectic mixt. of lithium and potassium acetate with water-to-cation ratio as low as 1.3. Our work suggests an important direction for the practical realization of safe, low-cost, and high-performance aq. Li-ion batteries.

The emergence of "water-in-salt" carbon-based supercapacitors presents great potential for further improving the energy d., owing to the extended electrochem. stability window. However, not only low cond. and high viscosity hinder the superior rate performance, but also the high cost of salts limits their commercialization. Here, we report a low-cost concd. sodium nitrate electrolyte for high-performance and ultra-stable supercapacitors, based on good electrochem. stability, high cond., and low viscosity. In the wide operation voltage range of 0-2.1 V, the constructed sym. supercapacitor based on com. active carbon exhibits a high specific capacitance of 32.68 F g-1 at 1 A g-1. Moreover, superior rate capability (83% capacitance retention from 1 to 20 A g-1) and excellent cycle stability (90% capacitance retention after 9000 cycles) are also demonstrated. Consequently, this electrolyte system could be the most attractive candidate for promising carbon-based supercapacitors to further improve the energy d.

Using mol. dynamics simulations, small-angle neutron scattering, and a variety of spectroscopic techniques, the authors evaluated the ion solvation and transport behaviors in aq. electrolytes contg. bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide. At high salt concns. (from 10 to 21 mol/kg), a disproportion of cation solvation occurs, leading to a liq. structure of heterogeneous domains with a characteristic length scale of 1 to 2 nm. This unusual nano-heterogeneity effectively decouples cations from the Coulombic traps of anions and provides a 3-dimensional percolating Li-H2O network, via which 40% of the Li cations are liberated for fast ion transport even in concn. ranges traditionally considered too viscous. Due to such percolation networks, superconcd. aq. electrolytes were characterized by a high Li-transference no. (0.73), which is key to supporting an assortment of battery chemistries at high rate. The in-depth understanding of this transport mechanism establishes guiding principles to the tailored design of future superconcd. electrolyte systems.

Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have been deployed in a wide range of energy-storage applications and helped to revolutionize technol. development. Recently, a LIB that uses superconcd. salt water as its electrolyte has been developed. However, the role of water in facilitating fast ion transport in such highly concd. electrolyte solns. is not fully understood yet. Here, femtosecond IR spectroscopy and mol. dynamics simulations are used to show that bulk-like water coexists with interfacial water on ion aggregates. We found that dissolved ions form intricate 3-dimensional ion-ion networks that are spontaneously intertwined with nanometric water H-bonding networks. Then, hydrated Li ions move through bulk-like water channels acting like conducting wires for Li ion transport. Our exptl. and simulation results indicate that water structure-breaking chaotropic anion salts with a high propensity to form ion networks in aq. solns. would be excellent candidates for water-based LIB electrolytes. We anticipate that this work will provide guiding principles for developing aq. LIB electrolytes.

In aq. electrolyte batteries, the salt concn. of the electrolyte affects the ionic cond., which will further affect the rate performance of the battery as well as the diffusion of reactive species that can cause self-discharge, particularly in thick electrode devices. To this end, the implications are explored of device performance using Na0.44MnO2 cathode material, NaTi2(PO4)3, anode material in a NaClO4-based aq. solns. with molarities as high as 5. Expts. included phys. property characterizations, cyclic voltammetry, and const. current charging/discharging methods. Preliminary results indicate that, in cells with thick electrodes (∼1 mm), rate capability and electrode utilization increased significantly with higher molarity solns.: capacity at the 1.5 C rate increased 38% by increasing the salt concn. from 1-5 M. At the same time the oxygen-related self-discharge phenomenon was diminished when using higher electrolyte molarities, though there was still measurable loss in capacity in the electrodes. Irreversible capacity loss was obsd. to occur even in electrolytes with the lowest oxygen content, suggesting that self discharge and capacity loss are not necessarily causally related.

Given the safety and cost involved, aq. electrolyte is an extremely attractive candidate for large-scale energy storage systems. However, limited electrochem. stability window of water (decompn. potential <1.23 V) usually confines the energy d. of aq. energy storage systems. Herein, an aq. electrolyte based on NaClO4 soln. with a high concn. of 17 m is demonstrated to enlarge the practical stability window to approx. 2.75 V, because the scarcity of free water mols. in high salt concn. contributes to their inactivity. An aq. sodium-ion hybrid capacitor is assembled by using the electrolyte and could be operated at a large voltage of 2.0 V, in which arom. polyimide (PI) is used as anode material and ultrahigh sp. surface PI derived porous carbon microspheres as cathode. This enhanced electrochem. window of the aq. electrolyte ensures that the sodium-ion capacitor delivers an energy d. of 65.1 Wh kg-1 with high power d. and good cycle stability. Most importantly, compared to most used host materials with conventional intercalation mechanisms, fast reaction kinetics and structural insensitivity of PI to the ion radius are responsible for the excellent sodium storage properties.

A review. In mol. and cellular biol., dissolved ions and mols. have decisive effects on chem. and biol. reactions, conformational stabilities, and functions of small to large biomols. Despite major efforts, the current state of understanding of the effects of specific ions, osmolytes, and bioprotecting sugars on the structure and dynamics of water H-bonding networks and proteins is not yet satisfactory. Recently, to gain deeper insight into this subject, we studied various aggregation processes of ions and mols. in high-concn. salt, osmolyte, and sugar solns. with time-resolved vibrational spectroscopy and mol. dynamics simulation methods. It turns out that ions (or solute mols.) have a strong propensity to self-assemble into large and polydisperse aggregates that affect both local and long-range water H-bonding structures. In particular, we have shown that graph-theor. approaches can be used to elucidate morphol. characteristics of large aggregates in various aq. salt, osmolyte, and sugar solns. We anticipate that the combination of graph theory and mol. dynamics simulation methods will be of exceptional use in achieving a deeper understanding of the fundamental phys. chem. of dissoln. and in describing the interplay between the self-aggregation of solute mols. and the structure and dynamics of water.

Carrying out mol. dynamics simulations and graph theor. analyses of high salt solns., and comparing numerically calcd. vibrational spectroscopic properties of water with femtosecond IR pump-probe exptl. data, we have recently found that ions in high salt solns. can form two morphol. different ion aggregate structures. In the cases of NaCl solns., Na+ and Cl- tend to form compact cluster-like ion aggregate in high NaCl solns. In contrast, K+ and SCN- form spatially extended network-like ion aggregates that also exhibit a percolating network behavior. Interestingly, a variety of graph theor. properties of ion network in high KSCN solns. were found to be very similar to those of water H-bonding network. It was shown that spatially extended ion networks in high KSCN solns. are completely intertwined with water H-bonding networks, which might be the key to understand the high soly. of thiocyanate salts in water. Here, we further consider two salts that have been extensively studied exptl. by using femtosecond IR pump-probe technique, which are NaClO4 and NaBF4. Note that ClO-4 and BF-4 are well-known chaotropic ions that have been believed to behave as water structure breaker. To understand how such chaotropic ions affect water H-bonding structure, we carried out spectral graph analyses of mol. dynamics simulation data of these aq. solns. Graph spectra and degree distribution of ion aggregates formed in high NaBF4 and NaClO4 solns. show that these chaotropic anions also have a strong propensity to form ion networks. The fact that salts contg. chaotropic ions like SCN-, BF-4, and ClO-4 have very high soly. limits in water could then be related to our observation that these chaotropic anions with counter cations in high salt solns. are capable of forming intricate ion networks intertwined with water H-bonding networks. We anticipate that the present graph theor. anal. method would be of use in further studying both various anomalous behaviors of interfacial water and fundamental phys. chem. of mixing and salt soly. in water. From the viewpoint of the cost and safety, aq. sodium-ion batteries are attractive candidate for large-scale energy storage. Although the operating voltage range of the aq. battery is theor. limited to 1.23 V by the electrochem. decompn. of water, the voltage restriction is a little bit eased in real aq. battery system by the charge/discharge overvoltage. Effect of the concd. electrolyte on the operation voltage was studied in aq. Na-ion battery with Na2MnFe(CN)6 hexacyanoferrates cathode and NaTi2(PO4)3 NASICON-type anode, in order to increase the discharge voltage. According to the cyclic voltammetry, the electrochem. window of dild. 1 mol kg-1 NaClO4 aq. electrolyte is only 1.9 V, whereas the corresponding electrochem. window of concd. 17 mol kg-1 NaClO4 aq. electrolyte is widen to 2.8 V. This wide electrochem. window of the concd. aq. electrolyte allows the Na2MnFe(CN)6//NaTi2(PO4)3 aq. sodium-ion system to work reversibly. By contrast, the framework of Na2MnFe(CN)6 cathode was destroyed by the hydroxide anion generated in dild. 1 mol kg-1 electrolyte.

However, the need for generally high-cost org. solutes in the high-concn. electrolyte has become another major obstacle. Herein, we revisited all the commonly used low-cost solutes for high-concn. system and discovered that the use of NaClO4 solute effectively results in a wide electrochem. stability window by suppressing water decompn. and induces stable solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer formation without involving the redn. of salt anions. Carbon-based supercapacitors have been widely used in elec. vehicles because of their high-power d., long cycle life and fast charge/discharge rates. However, low volumetric energy d. severely limits their application for miniaturized electronic devices. Here, we have demonstrated a carbon-based sym. supercapacitor by using a three-dimensional porous graphene with high d. as the electrode material and a 17 M NaClO4 water-in-salt electrolyte with a 2.1 V electrochem. stability window. The device exhibited high specific capacitance (145.3 F cm-3 at 0.5 A g-1), excellent rate performance (70.0% capacitance retention even at 50 A g-1), high volumetric energy d. (22.3 Wh L-1 at 333.4 W L-1 based on the total mass of active materials) and excellent cycle stability with 99.1% capacitance retention after 10,000 cycles at 5 A g-1. The performance of this device was superior to the most current supercapacitors based on carbon materials. This effective dual-strategy of simultaneously regulating capacitance and potential window can greatly promote the further development of aq. carbon-based supercapacitors.

Elec. double-layer capacitors (DLCs) can have high storage capacity, but their porous electrodes cause them to perform like resistors in filter circuits that remove ripple from rectified d.c. We have demonstrated efficient filtering of 120-Hz current with DLCs with electrodes made from vertically oriented graphene nanosheets grown directly on metal current collectors. This design minimized electronic and ionic resistances and produced capacitors with RC time consts. of less than 200 μs, in contrast with ~1 s for typical DLCs. Graphene nanosheets have a preponderance of exposed edge planes that greatly increases charge storage as compared with that of designs that rely on basal plane surfaces. Capacitors constructed with these electrodes could be smaller than the low-voltage Al electrolyte capacitors that are typically used in electronic devices.

The recent boom in multifunction portable electronic equipments requires the development of compact and miniaturized electronic circuits with high efficiencies, low costs and long lasting time. For the operation of most line-powered electronics, a.c. (ac) line-filters are used to attenuate the leftover ac ripples on d.c. (dc) voltage busses. Today, aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs) are widely applied for this purpose. However, they are usually the largest components in electronic circuits. Replacing AECs by more compact capacitors will have an immense impact on future electronic devices. Here, we report a double-layer capacitor based on three-dimensional (3D) interpenetrating graphene electrodes fabricated by electrochem. redn. of graphene oxide (ErGO-DLC). At 120-Hz, the ErGO-DLC exhibited a phase angle of -84 degrees, a specific capacitance of 283 microfaradays per cm square and a resistor-capacitor (RC) time const. of 1.35 ms, making it capable of replacing AECs for the application of 120-Hz filtering.

A high volumetric energy d., and hence compactness, is an essential property for the supercapacitors needed to replace the bulky aluminum electrolytic capacitors currently used for a.c. (AC) line filtering. In this paper, we demonstrate the fabrication of AC-line-filtering supercapacitors with unprecedentedly high volumetric energy densities (Evol ≈ 4.1 mW h cc-1 at 120 Hz). This high d. is achieved by using ultrathin and dense carbon nanotube (CNT) films as electrodes (t ≈ 300 nm, d ≈ 1.1 g cc-1). Importantly, the mesopores and short pore length of the ultrathin films enable sufficiently fast electrolyte ion movement, even with org. electrolytes, for AC line filtering (impedance phase angle, .vphi. ≈ -82.2° at 120 Hz). The use of org. electrolytes extends the operating voltage window (V = 2.5 V), and therefore significantly increases the energy d. (Evol .varies. V2). Moreover, we show that a gold insertion layer provides the excellent interfacial qualities between the CNTs and aluminum current collector that are required for fast-response applications. Our findings may greatly advance supercapacitor research and technol. for emerging high-frequency applications.

Replacing the bulky aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs) used extensively in AC line filtering with a compact supercapacitor would contribute greatly to the miniaturization of electronic devices. However, the supercapacitors developed for AC line filtering have limited application voltages of ≤∼20 V. To extend the range of application voltages, it is essential to design carbon electrode materials with a suitable pore structure. This paper reports that graphitic ordered mesoporous carbon (GOMC) can be used as an electrode material in supercapacitors for AC line filtering applications. By utilizing the open pore structure of GOMC, which is also known as CMK-3, a 2.5 V supercapacitor with a high areal capacitance (Careal ∼ 560 μF cm-2 at 120 Hz) and a fast frequency response (.vphi. ∼ -80° at 120 Hz) was realized. Importantly, the addn. of a small amt. of CNTs to the CMK-3 results in the formation of an efficient elec. network between the individual CMK-3 particles. The successful conversion of a 60 Hz AC signal to a DC output was demonstrated using the supercapacitors. The advantages of the CMK-3/CNT supercapacitor over a com. AEC can be extended to applications up to ∼40 V.

Compact elec. double layer capacitors (EDLCs) can be applied to the AC line filtering process and potentially replace conventional bulky aluminum electrolytic capacitors. However, to realize the AC line filtering application, the energy d. of the EDLCs needs to be significantly increased while high power d. is maintained. In this work, we demonstrate the EDLCs fabricated with ordered mesoporous carbon, CMK-5, and small amts. of single walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs), which exhibit the highest areal energy d. among various EDLCs reported so far and power performance sufficient for AC line filtering. High energy d. of CMK-5/SWNT EDLCs can be attributed to high capacitance arising from the bimodal mesoporosity of CMK-5 and high operation voltage owing to the pores compatible with ion sizes in org. electrolytes. High power d. is ascribed to the high elec. cond. and straight ordered pore structure of CMK-5, enabling facile ion movements. Therefore, the carbon pore structure is one of the crit. factors to be controlled for the enhancement of the overall performance of EDLCs for AC line filtering. Our demonstration would greatly contribute to the scientific and technol. advancement of AC line filtering EDLCs.

Supercapacitors are generally more compact than conventional bulky aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs). Replacement of AECs with supercapacitors can lead to miniaturization of electronic devices. However, even state-of-the-art supercapacitors developed in labs. are superior to or competitive with AECs only in low voltage applications (<∼40 V). In order to improve the voltage limits of current supercapacitors, we have incorporated Ketjen black (KB) as an electrode material. Utilizing the open pore structure and the graphitic nature of KB, we demonstrate that the voltage limit can be extended to 53 V. The KB supercapacitor exhibits excellent areal capacitance, cell voltage, and phase angle values of ∼574 μF cm-2, 2.8 V, and ∼-80°, resp. In addn., we demonstrate that an AC line filtering circuit with three supercapacitors connected in series can extend the application voltage without significant sacrifice in rate capability (.vphi. ∼ -77° at 120 Hz). On the other hand, KBs are much less expensive than carbon materials previously demonstrated for AC line filtering and hence are very attractive for practical applications. We believe that this demonstration of high-performance supercapacitors made from low-cost carbon materials is both scientifically interesting and important for practical applications.

Activated carbon materials have been playing a significant role in addressing the challenges posed with the ever-increasing demand for alternative clean and sustainable energy technologies. In the present study, a facile strategy is proposed for generating porosity in porous carbons by using carton box as the precursor and eutectic NaOH-KOH melt as the activating agent. The prepd. carbon materials have a very high sp. surface area up to 2731 m2 g-1 with large pore vol. of 1.68 cm3 g-1, which is greater than that of only KOH was used at the same mass ratio. Electrochem. studies based on sym. supercapacitor devices demonstrating that the NaOH-KOH melt activated porous carbon exhibits significantly improved rate capability in the range of 0.5-75 A g-1 despite of the similar specific capacitance with respect to KOH activated carbon at a low c.d. of 0.5 A g-1. The remarkable deviations in capacitive behavior at high c.d. for the NaOH-KOH melt activated porous carbon and KOH activated samples highlighting the sp. surface area is not the only parameter that dets. the capacitive performance esp. at high charge-discharge rate.

Notably, many significant breakthroughs for a new generation of supercapacitors have been reported in recent years, related to theor. understanding, material synthesis and device designs. Herein, we summarize the state-of-the-art progress toward mechanisms, new materials, and novel device designs for supercapacitors. Firstly, fundamental understanding of the mechanism is mainly focused on the relationship between the structural properties of electrode materials and their electrochem. performances based on some in situ characterization techniques and simulations. Secondly, some emerging electrode materials are discussed, including metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), covalent org. frameworks (COFs), MXenes, metal nitrides, black phosphorus, LaMnO3, and RbAg4I5/graphite. Thirdly, the device innovations for the next generation of supercapacitors are provided successively, mainly emphasizing flow supercapacitors, a.c. (AC) line-filtering supercapacitors, redox electrolyte enhanced supercapacitors, metal ion hybrid supercapacitors, micro-supercapacitors (fiber, plane and three-dimensional) and multifunctional supercapacitors including electrochromic supercapacitors, self-healing supercapacitors, piezoelec. supercapacitors, shape-memory supercapacitors, thermal self-protective supercapacitors, thermal self-charging supercapacitors, and photo self-charging supercapacitors. Finally, the future developments and key tech. challenges are highlighted regarding further research in this thriving field.

Electrochem. capacitors (ECs) are slow devices with charging and discharging rates limited below 1 Hz. They run at d.c. and function as power source, but cannot afford the role of a conventional capacitor for current ripple filtering or pulse energy harvesting. Recently, developing ultrafast ECs that work at hundreds to kilohertz (kHz) frequency scope have attracted great interests, with the aim to replace the traditional aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs) that have bulky size and large equiv. series resistance. Compact kHz ECs would produce huge impacts on power design, power electronics and environmental pulse energy harvesting. Towards such a goal, the electrode material and its nanostructure are the keys to boost the response frequency of an EC from below 1 Hz to above 1 kHz. In this Review, we summarize guidelines on the electrode nanostructure design for kHz response, discuss the various carbonaceous materials and other highly conductive materials based electrode structures for kHz ECs. The configurations of higher voltage kHz ECs, and their dimension advantage over AECs are critically evaluated, followed with the outlook on the further study and development in this promising area.

In this work, N2 adsorption was employed to investigate the effects of carbon support, platinum, and ionomer loading on the microstructure of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell catalyst layers. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller and t-plot analyses of adsorption isotherms and pore-size distributions were used to study the microstructure of carbon supports, platinum/carbon catalyst powders, and three-component platinum/carbon/ionomer catalyst layers. Two types of carbon supports were chosen for the investigation: Ketjen Black and Vulcan XC-72. Catalyst layers with a range of Nafion ionomer loadings were studied in order to evaluate the effect of an ionomer on the catalyst layer microstructure. Regions of adsorption were differentiated into micropores assocd. with the carbon primary particles (<2 nm), mesopores ascribed to the void space inside agglomerates (2-20 nm), and mesoporous to macroporous space inside aggregates of agglomerates (>50 nm). Ketjen Black was found to possess a significant fraction of micropores, 25% of the total pore vol., in contrast to Vulcan XC-72, for which the corresponding fraction of micropores was 15% of the total pore vol. The microstructure of the carbon support was found to be a significant factor in the formation of the microstructure in the three-component catalyst layers, serving as a rigid porous framework for distribution of platinum and the ionomer. It was found that platinum particle deposition on Ketjen Black occurs in, or at the mouth of, the support micropores, thus affecting its effective microporosity, whereas platinum deposition on Vulcan XC-72 did not significantly affect the support microstructure. The codeposition of ionomer in the catalyst layer strongly influenced its porosity, covering pores <20 nm, which are ascribed to the pores within the primary carbon particles (pore sizes <2 nm) and to the pores within agglomerates of the particles (pore sizes of 2-20 nm).

A platinum free counter electrode for dye sensitized solar cells was developed using graphene platelets (GP) supported nickel nanoparticles (NPs) as the active catalyst. Few layered GP were prepd. by chem. oxidn. of graphite powders followed by thermal exfoliation and redn. The nanoparticles of nickel were deposited directly onto the platelets by pulsed laser ablation. The composite electrodes of GP and Ni nanoparticles (GP-Ni) thus obtained showed better performance compared to conventional Pt thin film electrodes (Std Pt) and unsupported Ni NPs. The efficiencies of the cells fabricated using GP-Ni, Std Pt and Ni NP CEs were 2.19%, 2% and 1.62%, resp. The GP-Ni composite solar cell operated with an open circuit voltage of 0.7 V and a fill factor of 0.6. Electrochem. impedance spectroscopy using the I3-/I- redox couple confirms lower values of charge transfer resistance for the composite electrodes, 4.67 Ω cm2 as opposed to 7.73 Ω cm2 of Std Pt. The better catalytic capability of these composite materials is also reflected in the stronger I3- redn. peaks in cyclic voltammetry scans.

Few-layer graphene (FLG) has been predicted to exist in various crystallog. stacking sequences, which can strongly influence the material's electronic properties. We demonstrate an accurate and efficient method to characterize stacking order in FLG using the distinctive features of the Raman 2D-mode. A review. Raman spectroscopy is an integral part of graphene research. It is used to det. the no. and orientation of layers, the quality and types of edge, and the effects of perturbations, such as elec. and magnetic fields, strain, doping, disorder and functional groups. This, in turn, provides insight into all sp2-bonded carbon allotropes, because graphene is their fundamental building block. Here we review the state of the art, future directions and open questions in Raman spectroscopy of graphene. We describe essential phys. processes whose importance has only recently been recognized, such as the various types of resonance at play, and the role of quantum interference. We update all basic concepts and notations, and propose a terminol. that is able to describe any result in literature. We finally highlight the potential of Raman spectroscopy for layered materials other than graphene.

The redox-active electrolyte supercapacitor (RAES) is a relatively new type of energy storage device. Simple addn. of selected redox species in the electrolyte can greatly enhance the energy d. of supercapacitors relative to traditional elec. double layer capacitors (EDLCs) owing to redox reactions. Studies on the kinetics at the interface of the electrode and redox mediator are important when developing RAESs. In this work, we employ highly accurate scanning electrochem. microscopy (SECM) to ext. the kinetic consts. at carbon/hydroquinone interfaces. The charge transfer rate consts. are 1.2 × 10-2 and 1.3 × 10-2 cm s-1 for the carbon nanotube/hydroquinone and reduced graphene oxide/hydroquinone interfaces, resp. These values are higher than those obtained by the conventional cyclic voltammetry method, approx. by an order of magnitude. The evaluation of heterogeneous rate consts. with SECM would be the cornerstone for understanding and developing high performance RAESs.

Ions in concd. salt solns. have a strong propensity to form polydisperse ion aggregates with broad size and shape distributions. In a series of previous comparative investigations using femtosecond IR pump-probe spectroscopy, mol. dynamics simulation, and graph theor. anal., we have shown that there exists a morphol. difference in the structures of ion aggregates formed in various salt solns. As salt concn. increases, the ions in such solns. form either cluster-like structures excluding water mols. or network-like structures entwined with water hydrogen-bonding networks. Interestingly, such morphol. characteristics of the ion aggregates have been found to be in correlation with the soly. limits of salts. An important question that still remains unexplored is why certain salts with different cations have notably different soly. limits in water. Here, carrying out a series of mol. dynamics simulations of aq. salt solns. and analyzing the distributions and connectivity patterns of ion aggregates with a spectral graph anal. method, we establish the relationship between the salt soly. and the ion aggregate morphol. with a special emphasis on the cationic effects on water structures and ion aggregation. We anticipate that the understanding of large scale ion aggregate structures revealed in this study will be crit. for elucidating the specific ion effects on the soly. and conformational stability of co-solute mols. such as proteins in water. The crit. aggregation phenomena are ubiquitous in many self-assembling systems. Ions in high salt solns. could also spontaneously form larger ion aggregates, but their effects on hydrogen-bond structures in water have long been controversial. Here, carrying out mol. dynamics (MD) simulation studies of high salt solns. and comparing the MD simulation results with IR absorption and pump-probe spectroscopy of O-D stretch mode of HDO in highly concd. salt solns. and 13C-NMR chem. shift of S13CN- in KSCN solns., we find evidence on the onset of ion aggregate and large-scale ion-ion network formation that concomitantly breaks water H-bond structure in certain salt solns. Despite that these exptl. results cannot provide direct evidence on the 3D morphol. structures of ion aggregates, they serve as ref. data for verifying MD simulation methods. The MD results suggest that disrupted water H-bond network is intricately intertwined with ion-ion network. This further shows morphol. variation of ion aggregate structures from ion cluster to ion network in high salt solns. that are interrelated to the onset of macroscopic aggregate formation and the water H-bond structure making and breaking processes induced by Hofmeister ions. Salts of the same anions of Mg2+, Na+, and Li+ exhibit different hygroscopic properties. These differences are attributed to the mol. structural properties of the H bonding network of the H2O mols. in the 2nd and 1st hydrated layers of Mg2+, Na+, and Li+. To study the structures of H2O mols., in particular, the presence of H2O monomers, Raman spectra of single levitated droplets of aq. NaClO4, LiClO4, and Mg(ClO4)2 solns. from dild. concns. to high supersaturations were measured. Because heterogeneous nucleation was suppressed in these levitated droplets, supersatd. droplets with a H2O-to-solute ratio (WSR) ≥2 was achieved. Taking advantage of the structure breaking effect of ClO-4on the H bonding network of H2O mols., Raman spectra of H2O monomers in these highly supersatd. droplets were obsd. At a low WSR, two peaks at 3549 and 3588 cm-1 for H2O monomers with one and two weak H bonds with ClO4- were obsd. for NaClO4 droplets. Compared with those of the NaClO4 droplets, the peaks of the H2O monomers in supersatd. LiClO4 and Mg(ClO4)2 droplets red shifted to 3553 and 3546 cm-1, resp. This observation is consistent with the order of the increase of the polarization effect of the cations, i.e., Na+ < Li+ < Mg2+. The intensity ratios of the strongly H-bonded components to the H2O monomers, i.e., I3440/I3549 and I3289/I3549 for NaClO4, I3455/I3553 and I3275/I3553 for LiClO4, and I3411/I3546 and I3440/I3549 for Mg(ClO4)2, were used to study the effects of the presence of ClO4- on the H2O structures of the hydration layers of Na+, Li+, and Mg2+. The results were explained in terms of the stability of H2O mols. in the inner spheres of these hydrated cations.

Aq. sodium-ion capacitors (ASICs) are becoming increasingly important due to the remarkable advantages of aq. electrolyte about the excellent ionic cond., non-flammability and low cost compared with org. systems. But, low capacitance of the elec. double-layer capacitive material and narrow potential window of aq. electrolyte both have neg. effects on the enhancement of energy d. Therefore, we employ typical pseudocapacitive material, layered MnO2/CNTs composite as cathode to fabricate sodium ion capacitor. It needs to be emphasized that the electrochem. process involves two kinds of energy storage mechanisms, such as the reversible Na+ adsorption/desorption onto the surface of each layer and fast Na+ (de)intercalation into the 2D interlayer space. Thus, the composite delivers a high specific capacitance (322.5 F g-1 at 0.5 A g-1) and an excellent cycle stability (5000 cycles with capacitance retention of approx. 90%). By means of the synergistic effects of the layered MnO2/CNTs cathode, sodium-ion water-in-salt electrolyte (NaWiSE) and polyimide org. anode, the as-assembled ASIC achieves a high energy d. of 78.5 Wh kg-1, accompanied by high power d. of 11000 W kg-1 and excellent cycle performance (even 77% capacity retention after 10000 cycles).

A review. The prodn. of sustainable hydrogen with water electrolyzers is envisaged as one of the most promising ways to match the continuously growing demand for renewable electricity storage. While so far regarded as fast when compared to the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) regained interest in the last few years owing to its poor kinetics in alk. electrolytes. Indeed, this slow kinetics not only may hinder the foreseen development of the anionic exchange membrane water electrolyzer (AEMWE), but also raises fundamental questions regarding the parameters governing the reaction. In this perspective, we first briefly review the fundamentals of the HER, emphasizing how studies performed on model electrodes allowed for achieving a good understanding of its mechanism under acidic conditions. Then, we discuss how the use of phys. descriptors capturing the sole properties of the catalyst is not sufficient to describe the HER kinetics under alk. conditions, thus forcing the catalysis community to adopt a more complex picture taking into account the electrolyte structure at the electrochem. interface. This work also outlines new techniques, such as spectroscopies, mol. simulations, or chem. approaches that could be employed to tackle these new fundamental challenges, and potentially guide the future design of practical and cheap catalysts while also being useful to a wider community dealing with electrochem. energy storage devices using aq. electrolytes.

High-frequency electrochem. capacitors or elec. double layer capacitor (HF-ECs) with large capacitance were developed from edge-oriented graphene (EOG) nanosheets perpendicularly grown around carbonized cellulose microfiber (CMF) sheets. Binder-free EOG/CMF electrodes were fabricated in a one-step 5-min plasma-enhanced chem. vapor deposition process, where cellulose fiber sheets were rapidly pyrolyzed by high-temp. plasma, while EOG simultaneously formed on the developing CMFs. Owing to combined unique characteristics of both EOG and CMF, such facilely produced electrodes exhibit excellent performance in terms of both high frequency response and high capacitance d. In aq. electrolyte cells, 10 μm thick EOG/CMF electrode exhibits an areal capacitance of 1.07 mF cm-2 at 120 Hz along with a frequency of 13.8 kHz at -45° phase angle. ∼3 V org. electrolyte cells show an areal capacitance of 0.49 mF cm-2 at 120 Hz, and a frequency of 1.47 kHz at -45° phase angle. Developed HF-ECs were successfully applied in practical applications as ripple current filter in line-frequency AC/DC conversion, and as pulse power storage/smoother in environmental energy harvesting for self-powered micro devices.

There are great needs in developing compact-size kilohertz (kHz) high-frequency (HF) electrochem. capacitors (ECs) for ripple current filtering and environmental vibration energy harvesting. However, the previously demonstrated electrodes are generally limited to a very small areal capacitance d. at 120 Hz due to sub-μm thick electrode used for meeting frequency requirement, which renders them unsuitable for practical ECs. Here, using crosslinked carbon nanofiber aerogel, derived from rapid microwave plasma pyrolysis of bacterial cellulose that was synthesized in a fermn. process, we demonstrated kHz HF-ECs with areal capacitance d. as high as 4.5 mF cm-2 at 120 Hz in an aq. electrolyte. The cruciality of plasma pyrolysis on high frequency response of the derived carbon nanofiber aerogel was discussed. The electrode performance in an org. electrolyte was further studied for operation in a large potential window of more than 3 V. Using such kHz HF-ECs, we further demonstrated their applications in rapid pulse energy storage for vibrational energy harvesting, as well as in ripple current filtering for AC/DC conversion. The promising results suggest this technol. has great potential for developing practical compact HF-ECs in substitution of electrolytic capacitors for several crucial applications.

A.c. (AC) line-filters are widely used to attenuate the leftover AC ripples in line-powered devices. However, the commercialized aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs) have low specific capacitances, making them usually the largest components in the electronic circuits of miniaturized, portable and/or flexible electronics. Herein, we report a scalable wet-process to fabricate an electrochem. capacitor (EC) using sulfuric acid treated com. available poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate) (AT-PEDOT:PSS) as an electrode material and graphite foil as the current collector. It exhibited high areal (994 μF cm-2) and volumetric (16.6 F cm-3) specific capacitances at 120 Hz, ultrahigh-rate frequency response (phase angle = -83.6° at 120 Hz) with a short resistor-capacitor time const. of 0.15 ms, and an excellent electrochem. stability. Therefore, it is promising to replace AECs for AC line-filtering, and their performance is superior to those of the state-of-the-art ECs for this purpose.

Filtering capacitor is a necessary component in the modern electronic circuit. Traditional filtering capacitor is often limited by its bulky and rigid configuration and narrow workable scope of applications. Here, an aqueous hybrid electrochemical capacitor is developed for alternating current line filtering with an applicable wide frequency range from 1 to 10,000 Hz. This capacitor possesses an areal specific energy density of 438 μF V(2) cm(-2) at 120 Hz, which to the best of our knowledge is record high among aqueous electrochemical capacitors reported so far. It can convert arbitrary alternating current waveforms and even noises to straight signals. After integration of capacitor units, a workable voltage up to hundreds of volts (e.g., 200 V) could be achieved without sacrificing its filtering capability. The integrated features of wide frequency range and high workable voltage for this capacitor present promise for multi-scenario and applicable filtering capacitors of practical importance.

The authors report the fabrication of high-performance, self-standing composite sp2-C supercapacitor electrodes using single-walled C nanotubes (CNTs) as conductive binder. The 3-dimensional mesoporous mesh architecture of CNT-based composite electrodes grants unimpaired ionic transport throughout relatively thick films and allows superior performance compared to graphene-based devices at an a.c. line frequency of 120 Hz. Metrics of 601 μF/cm2 with a -81° phase angle and a rate capability (RC) time const. of 199 μs are obtained for thin C films. The free-standing C films were obtained from a chlorosulfonic acid dispersion and interfaced to stainless steel current collectors with various surface treatments. CNT electrodes were able to cycle at 200 V/s and beyond, still showing a characteristic parallelepipedic cyclic voltammetry shape at 1 kV/s. Current densities are measured >6400 A/g, and the electrodes retain >98% capacity after 1 million cycles. These promising results are attributed to a redn. of series resistance in the film through the CNT conductive network and esp. to the surface treatment of the stainless steel current collector.

"Water-in-salt" electrolyte enables high-voltage aqueous lithium-ion chemistries
Suo, Liumin; Borodin, Oleg; Gao, Tao; Olguin, Marco; Ho, Janet; Fan, Xiulin; Luo, Chao; Wang, Chunsheng; Xu, Kang
Science (Washington, DC, United States)

(
American Association for the Advancement of Science

Lithium-ion batteries raise safety, environmental, and cost concerns, which mostly arise from their nonaq. electrolytes. The use of aq. alternatives is limited by their narrow electrochem. stability window (1.23 V), which sets an intrinsic limit on the practical voltage and energy output. We report a highly concd. aq. electrolyte whose window was expanded to ∼3.0 V with the formation of an electrode-electrolyte interphase. A full lithium-ion battery of 2.3 V using such an aq. electrolyte was demonstrated to cycle up to 1000 times, with nearly 100% coulombic efficiency at both low (0.15 C) and high (4.5 coulombs) discharge and charge rates.

Jiang, Liwei; Liu, Lilu; Yue, Jinming; Zhang, Qiangqiang; Zhou, Anxing; Borodin, Oleg; Suo, Liumin; Li, Hong; Chen, Liquan; Xu, Kang; Hu, Yong-Sheng

H2O-in-salt (WiS) electrolytes provide a new pathway to widen the electrochem. window of aq. electrolytes. However, their formulation strongly depends on the soly. of the chosen salts, imposing a stringent restriction on the no. of possible WiS systems. This issue becomes more severe for aq. Na-ion batteries (ANIBs) owing to the relatively lower soly. of Na salts compared to its alk. cousins (Li, K, and Cs). A new class of the inert-cation-assisted WiS (IC-WiS) electrolytes contg. the Et4N+ (TEA+) inert cation is reported. The Na IC-WiS electrolyte at a superhigh concn. of 31 mol kg-1 exhibits a wide electrochem. window of 3.3 V, suppresses transition metal dissoln. from the cathode, and ensures singular intercalation of Na into both cathode and anode electrodes during cycling, which is often problematic in mixed alkali cation systems such as K-Na and Li-Na. Owing to these unique advantages of the IC-WiS electrolyte, the NaTiOPO4 anode and Prussian blue analog Na1.88Mn[Fe(CN)6]0.97·1.35H2O cathode can be coupled to construct a full ANIB, delivering an av. voltage of 1.74 V and a high energy d. of 71 Wh kg-1 with a capacity retention of 90% after 200 cycles at 0.25 C and of 76% over 800 cycles at 1C.

Aq. electrolytes have shown extraordinary promise for safe electrochem. energy storage devices, but their widespread use is severely limited by the narrow electrochem. stability window (ESW). Here the great feasibility is demonstrated of using a superconcd. sodium perchlorate aq. soln. as a low-cost "water-in-salt" electrolyte to construct a high-performance carbon-based supercapacitor (SC). The attractive features of this electrolyte including wide ESW and excellent cond. enable the model SC to fully work at 2.3 V with superior rate capability and outstanding cycling stability. This SC exhibits a comparable energy d., a higher power d. and a much lower price compared to com. non-aq. SCs working at 2.7 V, representing significant progress toward practical applications.

Concentrated mixed cation acetate "water-in-salt" solutions as green and low-cost high voltage electrolytes for aqueous batteries
Lukatskaya, Maria R.; Feldblyum, Jeremy I.; Mackanic, David G.; Lissel, Franziska; Michels, Dominik L.; Cui, Yi; Bao, Zhenan

Electrolyte solns. are a key component of energy storage devices that significantly impact capacity, safety, and cost. Recent developments in "water-in-salt" (WIS) aq. electrolyte research have enabled the demonstration of aq. Li-ion batteries that operate with capacities and cyclabilities comparable with those of com. non-aq. Li-ion batteries. Critically, the use of aq. electrolyte mitigates safety risks assocd. with non-aq. electrolytes. However, the high cost and potential toxicity of imide-based WIS electrolytes limit their practical deployment. In this report, we disclose the efficacy of inexpensive, non-toxic mixed cation electrolyte systems for Li-ion batteries that otherwise provide the same benefits as current WIS electrolytes: extended electrochem. stability window and compatibility with traditional intercalation Li-ion battery electrode materials. We take advantage of the high soly. of potassium acetate to achieve the WIS condition in a eutectic mixt. of lithium and potassium acetate with water-to-cation ratio as low as 1.3. Our work suggests an important direction for the practical realization of safe, low-cost, and high-performance aq. Li-ion batteries.

The emergence of "water-in-salt" carbon-based supercapacitors presents great potential for further improving the energy d., owing to the extended electrochem. stability window. However, not only low cond. and high viscosity hinder the superior rate performance, but also the high cost of salts limits their commercialization. Here, we report a low-cost concd. sodium nitrate electrolyte for high-performance and ultra-stable supercapacitors, based on good electrochem. stability, high cond., and low viscosity. In the wide operation voltage range of 0-2.1 V, the constructed sym. supercapacitor based on com. active carbon exhibits a high specific capacitance of 32.68 F g-1 at 1 A g-1. Moreover, superior rate capability (83% capacitance retention from 1 to 20 A g-1) and excellent cycle stability (90% capacitance retention after 9000 cycles) are also demonstrated. Consequently, this electrolyte system could be the most attractive candidate for promising carbon-based supercapacitors to further improve the energy d.

Using mol. dynamics simulations, small-angle neutron scattering, and a variety of spectroscopic techniques, the authors evaluated the ion solvation and transport behaviors in aq. electrolytes contg. bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide. At high salt concns. (from 10 to 21 mol/kg), a disproportion of cation solvation occurs, leading to a liq. structure of heterogeneous domains with a characteristic length scale of 1 to 2 nm. This unusual nano-heterogeneity effectively decouples cations from the Coulombic traps of anions and provides a 3-dimensional percolating Li-H2O network, via which 40% of the Li cations are liberated for fast ion transport even in concn. ranges traditionally considered too viscous. Due to such percolation networks, superconcd. aq. electrolytes were characterized by a high Li-transference no. (0.73), which is key to supporting an assortment of battery chemistries at high rate. The in-depth understanding of this transport mechanism establishes guiding principles to the tailored design of future superconcd. electrolyte systems.

Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have been deployed in a wide range of energy-storage applications and helped to revolutionize technol. development. Recently, a LIB that uses superconcd. salt water as its electrolyte has been developed. However, the role of water in facilitating fast ion transport in such highly concd. electrolyte solns. is not fully understood yet. Here, femtosecond IR spectroscopy and mol. dynamics simulations are used to show that bulk-like water coexists with interfacial water on ion aggregates. We found that dissolved ions form intricate 3-dimensional ion-ion networks that are spontaneously intertwined with nanometric water H-bonding networks. Then, hydrated Li ions move through bulk-like water channels acting like conducting wires for Li ion transport. Our exptl. and simulation results indicate that water structure-breaking chaotropic anion salts with a high propensity to form ion networks in aq. solns. would be excellent candidates for water-based LIB electrolytes. We anticipate that this work will provide guiding principles for developing aq. LIB electrolytes.

In aq. electrolyte batteries, the salt concn. of the electrolyte affects the ionic cond., which will further affect the rate performance of the battery as well as the diffusion of reactive species that can cause self-discharge, particularly in thick electrode devices. To this end, the implications are explored of device performance using Na0.44MnO2 cathode material, NaTi2(PO4)3, anode material in a NaClO4-based aq. solns. with molarities as high as 5. Expts. included phys. property characterizations, cyclic voltammetry, and const. current charging/discharging methods. Preliminary results indicate that, in cells with thick electrodes (∼1 mm), rate capability and electrode utilization increased significantly with higher molarity solns.: capacity at the 1.5 C rate increased 38% by increasing the salt concn. from 1-5 M. At the same time the oxygen-related self-discharge phenomenon was diminished when using higher electrolyte molarities, though there was still measurable loss in capacity in the electrodes. Irreversible capacity loss was obsd. to occur even in electrolytes with the lowest oxygen content, suggesting that self discharge and capacity loss are not necessarily causally related.
